Question:
Could someone help explain what I am confused from the lecture note?:

Hello, this is from what we covered in class today. I am confused how we got the result of the two summations that are highlighted. Thank you in advance.
Answer:
the first one is simply saying 1+1+1+...+1, n times since i goes from 1 to n, so that sum is n

for the second one, the result is equivalent to $$\frac{n}{2}(n+1)$$. to see why this form is true, consider pairing up 1 with the last number n, 2 with the second last number n-1, and adding these pairs. you'll see that each pair adds to $$n+1$$. since we have n numbers, there are n/2 pairs, hence the sum is the sum of each pair multiplied by the number of pairs, or $$\frac{n}{2}(n+1)$$

Question:
Definite integral:

Can someone explain the last two sentences about the norm and Sn, with graph would be the best.
Answer:
$$P_n$$ refers to a partition of $$[a,b]$$ consisting of n-subintervals, $$\{P_n\}$$ is a sequence of these partitions of $$[a,b]$$ - so as n gets large our partition, $$P_n$$, consists of more sub-intervals, and as stated on Pg. 13 of the course notes $$\|P_n\| = max\{\Delta t_1, \Delta t_2, \cdots, \Delta t_n\}$$, which is the length of the largest sub-interval.

Also, $$\{S_n\}$$ refers to the sequences of Riemann sums associated with the $$P_n$$'s, where $$S_n = \sum_{i=0}^{n}f(c_i)\Delta t_i$$. Where our $$\Delta t_i$$ is the length of our ith sub-interval of our partition $$P_n$$ and our $$c_i$$ is a value in our ith sub-interval of our partition $$P_n$$.

Putting these together we see that the statement is saying:

If there exists a unique value $$I \in \mathbb{R}$$ such that if we have any sequence of partitions which satisfy $$\lim_{n \to \infty}\|P_n\| = 0$$, i.e. our largest sub-interval goes to zero as n goes to $$\infty$$, then for any sequence of Riemann sums associated with these $$P_n$$'s we have that the limit of our sequence of Riemann sums approaches this unique value $$I$$, i.e. $$\lim_{n \to \infty} S_n = I$$.

Notice: This tells us that IF our function in integrable, we may partition $$[a,b]$$ in ANY way as long as the largest sub-interval of this partition gets really small as $$n \to \infty$$ and we may choose any $$c_i \in [t_{i-1},t_i]$$ for our Riemann sums and we will still get the same unique value of $$I$$ for our integral.

I googled "desmos riemann sum visualization" and found this: https://www.desmos.com/calculator/tgyr42ezjq . I think this does a really good job showing what is happening as you change the value of n - the norm of our partitions become smaller and our Riemann sums become a better approximation of the area under the curve as n gets large. However, note that in this visualization the partitions are "regular n-partitions" and the $$c_i$$'s are all chosen in the same way both of which our theorem doesn't require us to do!

Question:
Lecture One Questions:

I am a bit confused on a few things from class and wanted some clarification. Thank you in advance!

1. For the summation shown below, it's trying to represent the the estimate of the area right? As in, it would be (1/10 * 1/100) + (1/10 * 4/100)+......

. 

2. I noticed in our lessons and the videos posted in the weekly practice problems that we used the second formula (as shown below in the picture) a lot. I was wondering if how the summation equals the right side was something we learned in class, or just a formula we have to know

3. What does Sn and S represent in this limit? (eg. area, sum of the rectangles?) Is this true for all sequences?
Answer:
1. Yes, the sum represents the area of the sum of the rectangles which is an estimate of the area under the curve.

2. If a "calculate the Riemann sum" question appears on a evaluation the required summation formulas would be provided. The proofs/derivations of these formulas is something that may have been covered in Math 135 and they can be proved by induction (or by construction).

3. $$S_n$$ represents the Riemann Sum of a partition $$P_n$$, in the picture you provided for your first question we could call this sum $$S_{10}$$ as it represents the Riemann sum of a partition with 10 sub-intervals. More intuitively, $$S_n$$ represents the area of the rectangles which we are using to approximate the area under the curve. In this limit that you provided, the value of $$s$$ would be the value of the area under the curve (if the function is integrable), i.e. the limit value of the sequence of $$S_n$$'s.

Note: The value $$s$$ is really just the limit of a sequence (since each $$S_n$$ is really just a number which represents the area of a collection of rectangles) and so if the sequence $$\{S_n\}$$ doesn't converge then this $$s$$ doesn't exist. There do exist functions where $$\lim_{n \to \infty}\{S_n\}$$ does not exist for any partition depending on the chosen $$c_i$$'s (see question 4 on the practice problems). There are also functions where $$\lim_{n \to \infty}\{S_n\}$$ is not the same for every sequence of $$S_n$$'s and can vary depending on the chosen values of $$c_i$$ or the partition. Thus if we have an arbitrary function this is not necessarily true for all sequences $$\{S_n\}$$.

Aside: This is why we define integrable in the way that we do on page 15 of the course notes! We say that our function is integrable on $$[a,b]$$ if there exists a unique $$s \in \mathbb{R}$$ such that $$\lim_{n \to \infty}\{S_n\} = s$$ for any sequence of Riemann Sums, $$\{S_n\}$$, provided that our sequence of corresponding partitions satisfies $$\lim_{n\to\infty}\|P_n\|=0$$.

Question: Right-hand Riemann Sum: Do the Right-hand Riemann Sum and the Left-hand Riemann Sum have to be regular n-partition or not?
Answer: No, the Right-hand and Left-hand Riemann Sums do not require P to be a regular n-partition, see page 15 of the course notes.

Question: How do we get 1/n^3:
Answer:
As we see on page 15 of the course notes, we see that if $$P_n$$ is the regular n-partition we have that:

$$R_n = \sum_{i=1}^n f(a+i(\frac{b-a}{n})) (\frac{b-a}{n})$$

In this question we have that b = 1, a = 0, and f(x) = x^2. Substituting these in and simplifying gives us $$\frac{1}{n^3}\sum_{i=1}^n i^2$$, as desired.

note 2 properties question (f(x) > g(x)):

Question: Riemann Sum to Definite Int: If the bottom limit of the sum was 0 and the upper was n-1 would this be using left riemann sum? If so how does this change the way we approach the solution?
Answer:
The bottom limit of the sum being 0 and upper limit was $$(n-1)$$ this would amount to us labelling our sub-intervals differently. i.e. our zeroth interval would be $$[t_0, t_1]$$ - which normally we would say is our first interval and our $$\Delta t_0 = t_1 - t_0$$.

This would not be using a left Riemann sum. Our left and right Riemann sums refer to the $$c_i$$'s that we are choosing in the sub-intervals not the way that we label/index our sub-intervals.

Question:
PP1 Q2a Riemann Sum to Definite Integral:

For this question, how would we find what f(x) is? 

I know f(xi) = (e^xi)/xi = 1 + (6i/n)
Answer:
I think the best way to approach this is to first recall the definition of a Riemann Sum, as seen on page 13 of the course notes:

Given a function $$f$$ on $$[a,b]$$ and a partition $$P$$ on $$[a,b]$$, and a set $$\{c_1, c_2, \cdots, c_n\}$$ where $$c_i \in [t_{i-1},t_i]$$. Then a Riemann sum for $$f$$ with respect to $$P$$ is:

 $$S = \sum_{i=1}^{n}f(c_i)\Delta t_i$$

Notice that we are given that the $$x_i$$'s are a point in the $$i$$th sub-interval so these can be viewed as our $$c_i$$'s. We are also given that the partition is regular so we have that $$\Delta t_i = \frac{b-a}{n} = \frac{7-1}{n} = \frac{6}{n}$$.

Then by inspection we can see that our $$f(c_i) = f(x_i) = (\frac{e^{x_i}}{x_i})$$ and our $$\Delta t_i = \frac{6}{n}$$. From here we can use the definition of our definite integral on page 16 to write out the definite integral.

Note: I believe that when you state "$$f(x_i) = \frac{e^{x_i}}{x_i} = 1 + \frac{6i}{n}$$" you are assuming that we are using the Right-hand Riemann Sum which we cannot do in this case because we are not given that our $$x_i$$ is the right-hand endpoint of the $$i$$th subinterval.

Additionally notice that in the definition of the right-hand Riemann sum we have:

$$\sum_{i=1}^{n}(\textbf{f}(a+i(\frac{b-a}{n})) \ (\frac{b-a}{n}))$$

So, if we were doing the right hand Riemann sum we would have $$f(1 + \frac{6i}{n})$$.

The students' answer above is great! I'd just like to add two things:

For the first question, our $$\Delta x$$ refers to the length of a sub-interval (i.e. $$\Delta x_i = x_i - x_{i-1}$$), and note that these do not need to all be the same length. $$\|P_n\| = max\{\Delta x_1, \Delta x_2, \cdots, \Delta x_n\}$$ and this is the length of the largest sub-interval.

For the second question, the note says that it holds for all $$c \in \mathbb{R}$$, it then states that it even holds for $$c > b \textrm{ or } c < a$$. The purpose of stating this is to make it clear that this $$c$$ does not need to be in $$[a,b]$$ because as the student showed above it holds for all $$ c \in \mathbb{R}$$.

Question:
PP1 Q4:

Is my proof for question 4 of the practice problems valid/rigorous enough?
Answer: This observation will certainly be an important ingredient in the proof, but I'm not sure I'm convinced that this means the function isn't integrable. Being integrable means that the limit of every sequence of Riemann sums (associated to any sequence of partitions with $$\|P_n\|\rightarrow 0$$) is the same. Can you come up two sequences of Riemann sums that have different limits? That would show that the function is not integrable.

Question: General question about the definition of definite integral: How to understand the lower limit and upper limit represented by a and b?
Answer:
If I understand your question correctly you're asking what does the $$a$$ and the $$b$$ represent in the definite integral $$\int_{a}^{b}f(t) dt$$.

The interval $$[a,b]$$ is the interval which we are integrating over. So, if we picture integration as taking the area under the curve, then our $$a$$ represents the starting point along the x-axis of where we are computing the area and the $$b$$ represents the ending point along the x-axis of where we are computing our area.

Question:
Week one Content Questions:

I'm reviewing for the quiz and I had a few questions about this week's content. Thank you in advance!

1. From my understanding, delta t represents the width of one rectangle, not all of them, is this correct? Also, what is the second formula for? I'm confused about all the variables in this equations (eg. what that ti and t0 and delta t represent)

2.Assuming that the area above and below the x-axis are equal, the total area would be 0 right? So instead of ignoring the negative sign (of the area below the x axis), we simply subtract it from the "positive" area , right?

I

3. This might be a vague question but when going over the 6 properties, our prof drew an example to explain what the properties were trying to say but I forgot which one it was for. Im guessing it's 3 but I want to be sure.
Answer:
1) Yes, $$\triangle t$$ represents the width of one rectangle within our partition. When we have a regular-n partition (all the widths are equal) we can represent $$\triangle t = \frac{b-a}{n}$$ where $$b-a$$ is the length of the whole interval divided by $$n$$ subsections. 

The second formula is used as the terms to evaluate the function to solve the Riemann sum (possibly other applications I don't know about too). $$t_i$$ represents an arbitrary term within the partition, $$t_0$$ is the very first value in the interval (usually $$t_0 = a$$ from what I've seen, use this for practice problems), $$\triangle t$$ is the width of one rectangle. 

Basically what we're doing is computing a random instance of $$t$$ within our partition. 

Here's a diagram that will hopefully make more sense than my yapping:

$$t_i$$ is a placeholder for $$t_1, t_2, t_3, t_{whatever}...$$ within the interval. To calculate where it is in respect to $$t_0=a$$, we just add the width of 1 rectangle $$i$$ times. 

So if I want $$t_3$$, I would do $$t_3 = t_0 + 3\triangle t$$. I'm adding $$3\cdot$$ (width of rectangle) to get to $$t_3$$. Let me know if you can see this visually with my diagram, I can explain more if needed. Then you can plug this result in as the argument of your function within the definite integral and solve.

2. Yes, or you can think of it as "adding the negative area to the positive area". If they are equal then your total is 0. 

3. Your assumption is correct. This was for the 3rd property from 1.3 Thm 2 (pg. 28 of course note pdf)

Not sure if you wanted an explanation as to what this is talking about / how it relates to the diagram so just add a followup discussion if you'd like me to address that. 

Hope that helps, let me know if there's anything else I can add to clarify for you!

Question: class extra problem: I'm a little stuck with the calculation of the limit. How to get to the final result of e^2-1?
Answer:
You can pull out the constants, leaving you with 

$$\displaystyle 2(1-e^2)\frac{\displaystyle \lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}e^{\frac{2}{n}}}{\displaystyle \lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}n(1-e^{\frac{2}{n}})}$$.

The limit in the numerator should be easy enough to deal with. In the denominator, the limit has the form $$\infty\cdot 0$$, which is indeterminate. Perhaps L'Hopital's rule could help?

Question:
The Average Value Theorem:

Hi. I am a bit confused how we go from IVT to the geometric interpretation of the average value theorem? Why Area R1+Area R3 equals R2?
Answer:
If $$\alpha=f_{\text{avg}}$$, you're interested in the signed area between the graph of $$f(x)$$ and the horizontal line $$y=\alpha$$. Imagine applying a downward shift by $$\alpha$$ units to the function and to the line, so  $$y=\alpha$$ becomes $$y=0$$ (the $$x$$-axis) and $$f(x)$$ becomes $$f(x)-\alpha$$. Note that determining the signed area between $$f(x)$$ and $$y=\alpha$$ is the same as determining the signed area between $$f(x)-\alpha$$ and the $$x$$-axis.

What is the signed area between $$f(x)-\alpha$$ and the $$x$$-axis? I suppose it would be $$\displaystyle\int_a^b \left(f(x)-\alpha\right)\,dx$$. If you can show that this integral is $$0$$, I suppose that would show that there is the same amount of area below the $$x$$-axis as there is above. And since your problem is equivalent, it would mean that there is the same area above $$y=\alpha=f_{\text{avg}}$$ as there is below.

Now, can you prove that $$\displaystyle\int_a^b\left(f(x)-\alpha\right)\,dx=\int_a^b\left(f(x)-f_{\text{avg}}\right)\,dx=0$$?

If $$\alpha=f_{\text{avg}}$$, you're interested in the signed area between the $$f(x)$$ and the horizontal line $$y=\alpha$$. Imagine applying a downward shift by $$\alpha$$ units to the function and to the line, so  $$y=\alpha$$ becomes $$y=0$$ (the $$x$$-axis) and $$f(x)$$ becomes $$f(x)-\alpha$$. Note that determining the signed area between $$f(x)$$ and $$y=\alpha$$ is the same as determining the signed area between $$f(x)-\alpha$$ and the $$x$$-axis.

What is the signed area between $$f(x)-\alpha$$ and the $$x$$-axis? I suppose it would be $$\displaystyle\int_a^b \left(f(x)-\alpha\right)\,dx$$. If you can show that this integral is $$0$$, I suppose that would show that there is the same amount of area below the $$x$$-axis as there is above. And since your problem is equivalent, it would mean that there is the same area above $$y=\alpha=f_{\text{avg}}$$ as there is below.

Now, can you prove that $$\displaystyle\int_a^b\left(f(x)-\alpha\right)\,dx=\int_a^b\left(f(x)-f_{\text{avg}}\right)\,dx=0$$?

$$c$$ changes as $$h\rightarrow 0$$, but all the while, it must remain in the interval $$[x,x+h]$$. That is, $$x\leq c\leq x+h$$. What can you say about $$x$$ and $$x+h$$ as $$h\rightarrow 0$$? By the squeeze theorem, what does that tell you about $$c$$?

Question:
Problem regarding FTC part1:

Hi. This is a problem from a lecture note. Why do we need to have an intermediate value a? Do we have to have such a value when both of the upper and lower are not a fixed value?
Answer:
From the definition, if $$G(x) = \int_{a}^{x}f(t)dt,$$ then $$ G'(x) = f(x)$$. In order to apply this, the integral must be in the form $$ \int_{a}^{x}f(t)dt,$$ so the solution modifies the original integral by splitting it up into 2 integrals that each have some arbitrary constant $$a$$ in order to apply FTC part 1.

Question: if a function is integrable, is it continuous? (i.e is the converse of that theorem true):
Answer: No, this is not true. Not sure where it is in the course notes but there is a remark after the definition of integrability. It says that a function can also be integrable if it has a finite number of discontinuities. An example of this would be a jump discontinuity. We are going to learn how to integrate this later in the course, but for now the simple answer is integrability $$\not\Rightarrow$$ continuity! Hope that helps!

Question:
Integrability thm:

for the following theorem does it have to be regular n-partitions?
Answer:
Integrability means the limit of the Riemann sums is the same no matter what sequence you use (provided the associated partitions satisfy $$\displaystyle \lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}\|P_n\|=0$$). So, no, we don't need to use the regular partitions here.
Integrability means the limit of the Riemann sums is the same no matter what sequence you use (provided the associate partitions satisfy $$\displaystyle \lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}\|P_n\|=0$$). So, no, we don't need to use the regular partitions here. 
I think if it isn't regular n-partitions, it defeats the whole point of finding the exact area as $$n\to\infty$$. Because you want $$lim_{n \to\infty}||P_n|| = 0$$. If they aren't regular, you can always have $$n\to\infty$$ amount of partitions in but $$lim_{n \to\infty}||P_n|| \neq 0$$, i.e. you have an infinite amount of partitions in a small section with a huge partition. At that point, you'll just be calculating as if if the graph was only divided in one partition, even if there's an infinite amount of them, if that makes sense.

Question: Question about the definition of integrability: Can anyone explain why the formal definition requires that the limit of the norm of the partition is zero?
Answer: well if the limit of the norm didn't approach 0 as n approached infinity then that means that our rectangles would not become infinitely thin, resulting in our value still being an approximation rather than the exact value. The only reason we define the limit of the norm to approach 0 is because we want even the widest of the rectangles to become infinitely thin, making our sum of the rectangles, infinitely close to accuracy.

Question:
Does a general antiderivative of a function that isn't continous for all x have multiple constants?:

For example, today we learned in class the general antiderivative of $$\sec^2(x) $$  is $$\int \sec^2(x)dx = \tan(x) +C$$, but I was wondering why isn't this defined to have multiple values of $$C$$ since $$\tan(x)$$ isn't continuous for all $$x$$? Since there's infinite points where the function isn't defined, theoretically every interval of continuity could have a different constant. For example, a function $$f(x)$$ could be defined as $$f(x) = \tan(x) + C_1$$ on $$(\frac{-\pi }{2}, \frac{\pi }{2})$$, and  $$f(x) = \tan(x) + C_2$$ on $$(\frac{\pi }{2}, \frac{3\pi }{2})$$  and so on. This would still have a derivative of $$\sec^2(x)$$, but isn't of the form $$\tan(x) + C$$ since $$C_1$$ doesn't have to equal $$C_2$$.

Obviously if a function is continous for all $$x$$ then you can't apply this because functions with only one interval in the domain will have to be continous where the two intervals meet, meaning the $$C$$ will need to be the same. 

I'm wondering if in general this is true, and if so why don't we specify these conditions when writing the general antiderivative of a function?
Answer:
This is a great question. Yes, the "+C" term can be different on either side of a discontinuity.

For example, an antiderivative of $$\frac{1}{x^2}$$ is $$-\frac{1}{x}$$, and therefore we typically write the full collection of antiderivatives of $$\frac{1}{x^2}$$ as $$-\frac{1}{x}+C$$, $$C\in\mathbb{R}$$. You're correct, however, that we could use different constants here for $$x<0$$ and for $$x>0$$, since shifting the two pieces of the graph vertically won't affect the function's derivative. That is, something like

$$F(x)=\left\{\begin{array}{cc}-\frac{1}{x} + 1 & \text{if}\,\,x<0\\ -\frac{1}{x} +2 & \text{if}\,\,x>0\end{array}\right.$$

would also be an antiderivative.

My guess is that we don't go into such detail when reporting the antiderivatives of a function for two reasons. First, it would be a lot more cumbersome to write out our answers with that level of detail and it's just easier to remember that we could use different constant for different pieces of the function if we so desired. And second, this distinction isn't important when dealing with definite integrals, as the constants would cancel off when we substitute the bounds via the FTC.

For example, an antiderivative of $$\frac{1}{x^2}$$ is $$-\frac{1}{x}$$, and therefore we typically write the full collection of antiderivatives of $$\frac{1}{x^2}$$ is $$-\frac{1}{x}+C$$, $$C\in\mathbb{R}$$. You're correct, however, that we could use different constants here for $$x<0$$ and for $$x>0$$, since shifting the two pieces of the graph vertically won't affect the function's derivative. That is, something like

$$F(x)=\left\{\begin{array}{cc}-\frac{1}{x} + 1 & \text{if}\,\,x<0\\ -\frac{1}{x} +2 & \text{if}\,\,x>0\end{array}\right.$$

would also be an antiderivative.

My guess is that we don't go into such detail when reporting the antiderivatives of a function for two reasons. First, it would be a lot more cumbersome to write out our answers with that level of detail and it's just easier to remember that we could use different constant for different pieces of the function if we so desired. And second, this distinction isn't important when dealing with definite integrals, as the constants would cancel off when we substitute the bounds via the FTC.

Question:
How to tell if a Left/Right Riemann Sum will be an over/under estimate:

Hello,

I am a little confused on how we tell if a left/right sum will be an over/under estimate. I know that for a positive, increasing function, the right sum will be over and the left will be under, but beyond that I am not too sure, especially when the function is not strictly positive and we start dealing with negative area.

Is there some way of thinking that will lead you to knowing if there will be an over/under estimate of area?


Thank you!
Answer:
You cannot easily tell if the right or left Riemann sum will be an over or under estimate for every single function.

If it's increasing in an interval, you know that the rightmost point will be greatest, and the leftmost point will the the lowest.

The opposite is true if it's decreasing.

If you take the lowest points, you have an underestimate. If you take the greatest, you have an overestimate.

By taking the leftmost and rightmost points, you are taking the min / max points in the interval. This is only true of functions that only increase or functions that only decrease within an interval.

If you are given an interval that both decreases and increases in different subintervals; consider finding points where the derivative changes from negative to positive (and vice versa), then performing the Riemann sum for subintervals between those points. Then you can ensure you have an over/under estimate.

By taking the leftmost and rightmost points, you are taking the min / max points in the interval. This is only true of functions that only increase or functions that only decrease within an interval.

You cannot easily tell if the right or left Riemann sum will be an over or under estimate for every single function.

If it's an increasing function, you know that the rightmost point will be greatest, and the leftmost point will the the lowest.

The opposite is true of a decreasing function.

If you take the lowest points, you have an underestimate. If you take the greatest, you have an overestimate.

By taking the leftmost and rightmost points, you are taking the min / max points in the interval. This is only true of functions that only increase or functions that only decrease.

Question:

I've been using the limit of the sum and then L'Hopitals rule repeatedly to evaluate these.

Are both methods acceptable?
Answer: You're welcome to simplify the Riemann sum first and then take a limit at the end. But if you're using properties of limits or applying L'Hopital's rule, there needs to be "$$\displaystyle\lim$$" to indicate that you're talking about a limit.

Question: does the AVT hold if f is integrable but not continuous:
Answer:
You can add finitely many removable discontinuities wherever the average occurs for any continuous function, without changing the result; so it does not hold. You can add finitely many removable discontinuities wherever the average occurs for any continuous function, without changing the result; so it does not hold.

Consider the function $$f(x)=\left\{\begin{array}{cc} 0 & \text{if}\,\, 0\leq x\leq 1\\ 1 & \text{if}\,\, 1< x\leq 2 \end{array}\right.$$ for $$x\in[0,2]$$. Note that $$f$$ is integrable, as it is bounded and has only one discontinuity. Does $$f$$ ever attain its average value on $$[0,2]$$?

Question:

Answer: Both functions are integrable, since they have finitely many discontinuities, by the Remark on Page 17.

Question:
Definition of definite integral clarification:

Just to confirm, for the limit involving $$||P_n||$$, the $$n$$ in $$n\rightarrow \infty$$ is not the same $$n$$ as the one in $$||P_n||$$, right?

Because

- $$||P_n||$$ is the norm of any an element (a single partition) of the sequence of partitions $${P_n}$$

- $$n \rightarrow \infty$$ simply means that any partition (not the $$\infty$$-ith partition) with the number of subintervals approaching infinity
Answer:
||Pn|| denotes the width of the subinterval, this is saying as that width gets smaller
We have a sequence of partitions $$P_1, P_2, P_3,\ldots$$ here and want to ensure that the norms of the partitions are approaching $$0$$. That is, the sequence $$\|P_1\|,\|P_2\|,\|P_3\|,\ldots$$ should approach $$0$$.

eq0$$ at $$a$$. Things can go wrong if this hypothesis is not satisfied.

Question:
Question about changing variable:

In the technique of changing variable, we treated dy/dx as fraction. For example, I saw an example on the lecture $$u=5x^2, du/dx = 10x \Longrightarrow xdx = du/10$$. However, I remember clearly that in my high school. My Math teacher told me that dy/dx is not a fraction. So, is dy/dx a fraction or not?

Thank you
Answer:
<md>I think I've asked a similar question in this post: [moving dx around](https://piazza.com/class/lpvj0xmshic497/post/88), but no one has answered yet. You can also consult this post: [misleading to regard dy/dx as a fraction](https://mathoverflow.net/questions/73492/how-misleading-is-it-to-regard-fracdydx-as-a-fraction?_gl=1*tfwxez*_ga*MjU4Mzk2NTc1LjE2ODU5OTEyODg.*_ga_S812YQPLT2*MTcwNTc3MDI5OC4xMTkuMS4xNzA1NzcwMzc3LjAuMC4w.)
But I don't really understand some concepts that they discuss like cotangent space and nonstandard analysis.

I feel like it's more of a historical question. When Leibniz first introduced this notation, there was no $$\epsilon - \delta$$ analysis. Both dy and dx were defined as "infinitesimals" - quantities assumed to be infinitely small yet still non-zero. Although being intuitive, this notion contradicts the Archimedean Property of real numbers, because no matter how many times you add the "infinitesimals" to itself, it will never be greater than 1. 

Treating dy/dx works fine in some scenarios, ex. inverse function derivative (that's probably the most obvious one), chain-rule analogy, linearity of derivatives, u-substitution for integrals, and related rates. But it might fail in other cases, such as implicit differentiation (there appears a negative sign), partial derivatives for multi-variables, as well as higher dimensional manifolds. 

I will wait for an instructor to give a more reliable/persuasive viewpoint, but I personally treat them as "differential forms", “linear transformation”, and/or an "operator" for d/dx.</md>

Question: Practice Problem Q5: The answer assumes f is continuous, but the real integrand is f/x^2. How can we imply f/x^2 is also continuous from the assumption f is continuous?
Answer:
If $$f$$ is continuous, then the only issue for the continuity of $$f(x)/x^2$$ will be at $$x=0$$. The question states that $$x>0$$.

Perhaps you're concerned about the possibility that $$a$$ is negative. But note that since we are just asked to find one $$f$$ and one $$a$$ that make this equation true, let's work through the calculation assuming that we will indeed discovery a positive $$a$$ that works for us. Sure enough, we do: $$a=9$$.

If $$f$$ is continuous, then the only issue for the continuity of $$f(x)/x^2$$ will be at $$x=0$$. The question states that $$x>0$$.

Perhaps you're concerned about the possibility that $$a$$ is negative. But note that since we are just asked to find one $$f$$ and one $$a$$ that make this equation true, let's work through the calculation assuming that we will indeed arrive at an $$a>0$$. Sure enough, we find a positive $$a$$ that works: $$a=9$$.

Question:
Properties regarding integral of the multiplications of two functions:

Hi. Could anyone give a hint on how to apply properties on integrals regarding the multiplication of two functions?
Answer:
<md>I don't really understand what it means to recognize the geometrical area it represents (the function is not an odd function), but what I will do to compute this integral is to let t = 3 sinx, which will result in a value of 9$$\pi$$.</md>
I suspect the intended approach here is to separate the integral into two, recognize that $$\displaystyle\int_{-3}^3t\sqrt{9-t^2}\,dt=0$$ since the integrand is odd, and recognize that $$2\displaystyle\int_{-3}^3\sqrt{9-t^2}\,dt$$ is twice the area under the graph of $$y=\sqrt{9-t^2}$$, which is the graph of a familiar geometric shape. Hint: It might be easier to recognize this shape by squaring both sides of the equation $$y=\sqrt{9-t^2}$$.

Question:
Week Two Content Questions:

Thank you in advance!

1. Could someone explain the difference between an integral and the integral function. From my understanding, taking the integral is a mathematical operation that allows you to find the area under the curve. So what's the difference with the integral function we learned this week?

2. I'm confused about the difference between solving these two questions. For question one, we simply replaced the t with x and that was the answer (we didn't use chain rule to derive x^2). For the second one, we derived it and then swapped the t and x, how is that?
Answer:
1. The definite integral gives you a number (from a to b), which geometrically means the area under the curve, whereas the indefinite integral is a function (not uniquely defined). 2. Question one simply by FTCI, question two as you said, was because of the chain rule. > $$H(x) = \int_{2}^{x^2} sin(t^2)dt = G(x^2)$$ >>$$H'(x) = G'(x^2)\frac{d}{dx}(x^2)$$

Just to add to the answer for 1., the difference between and integral and the integral function is very similar to the difference between the derivative and the derivative function.

In Calc 1, you probably first learned how to calculate the slope of the tangent line (i.e., the derivative) at a specific point, and then realized that you can instead view the derivative as a function where we can plug in various $$x$$'s to get the slope of the tangent line at various points:

$$\displaystyle f^\prime(x)=\lim_{h\rightarrow 0}\frac{f(x+h)-f(x)}{h}.$$

This is exactly what we're doing with the integral in Calc 2. We first learned how to calculate the area under a graph on a particular interval $$[a,b]$$ (i.e., the integral $$\displaystyle\int_a^b f(t)\,dt$$), and later learned that we can actually view the integral as a function where we can plug in various $$x$$'s to get the area under the graph of $$f$$ on various intervals $$[a,x]$$:

$$G(x)=\displaystyle\int_a^xf(t)\,dt.$$

Just to add to the answer for 1., the difference between and integral and and integral function is very similar to the difference between the derivative and the derivative function.

In Calc 1, you probably first learned how to calculate the slope of the tangent line (i.e., the derivative) at a specific point, and then realized that you can instead view the derivative as a function where we can plug in various $$x$$'s to get the slope of the tangent line at various points:

$$\displaystyle f^\prime(x)=\lim_{h\rightarrow 0}\frac{f(x+h)-f(x)}{h}.$$

This is exactly what we're doing with the integral in Calc 2. We first learned how to calculate the area under a graph on a particular interval $$[a,b]$$ (i.e., the integral $$\displaystyle\int_a^b f(t)\,dt$$), and later learned that we can actually view the integral as a function where we can plug in various $$x$$'s to get the area under the graph of $$f$$ on various intervals $$[a,x]$$:

$$G(x)=\displaystyle\int_a^xf(t)\,dt.$$

Question:
Calculating integral using long division:

Hi. I am confused how the x^2 is separated from the fraction. And why it it is proper to separate the x^2?
Answer:
<md>As hinted by **"Polynomial long division"**, a technique you should have mastered in precalc. 
```
function n / d is
    require d ≠ 0
    q ← 0
    r ← n             // At each step n = d × q + r

    while r ≠ 0 and degree(r) ≥ degree(d) do
        t ← lead(r) / lead(d)       // Divide the leading terms
        q ← q + t
        r ← r − t × d

    return (q, r
```</md>

Question:
Trig Substitution:

Hello!

I'm wondering if we have to restrict the domain each time when needed. When it comes to a trig function "squared" under a square root, could we just assume it's positive and move on?

Thanks!
Answer:
The domain restriction is also needed to be able to go back to $$x$$'s from $$\theta$$'s. For example, if we use the substitution $$x=\tan\theta$$ in the integral below...

$$\displaystyle\int\frac{1}{1+x^2}\,dx = \int\frac{\sec^2\theta}{1+\tan^2\theta}\,d\theta=\int\frac{\sec^2\theta}{\sec^2\theta}\,d\theta=\int 1\,d\theta = \theta +C.$$

The final step of the calculation is to express our answer in terms of $$x$$ by noting that if $$x=\tan\theta$$, then $$\theta=\arctan(x)$$. But observe that the tangent function is not invertible unless we restrict its domain. Therefore, this final step only makes sense if $$\theta\in\left(\frac{-\pi}{2},\frac{\pi}{2}\right)$$ (or a similarly restricted domain, but this is the standard choice for arctan).

The domain restriction is also needed to be able to go back to $$x$$'s from $$\theta$$'s. For example, if we use the substitution $$x=\tan\theta$$ in the integral below...

$$\displaystyle\int\frac{1}{1+x^2}\,dx = \int\frac{\sec^2\theta}{1+\tan^2\theta}\,d\theta=\int\frac{\sec^2\theta}{\sec^2\theta}\,d\theta=\int 1\,d\theta = \theta +C.$$

The final step of the calculation is to expressour answer in terms of $$x$$ by noting that if $$x=\tan\theta$$, then $$\theta=\arctan(x)$$. But observe that the tangent function is not invertible unless we restrict its domain. Therefore, this final step only makes sense if $$\theta\in\left(\frac{-\pi}{2},\frac{\pi}{2}\right)$$ (or a similarly restricted domain, but this is the standard choice for arctan).

Question:
PP2 Q8f:

Hi can anyone explain this step please?

First, note that 1 − cos(4x) = 2 sin2(2x)

Is this a trig identity I am just forgetting about? Thanks.
Answer:
1-cos(4x)

=1-cos(2x+2x)

=1-(cos2(2x)-sin2(2x)) -> trig identity cos(x+y)=cos(x)cos(y)-sin(x)sin(y)

=1-(1-sin2(2x)-sin2(2x)) -> cos2(a) = 1-sin2(a)

=1-1+sin2(2x)+sin2(2x)

=2 sin2(2x)

Edit: An even easier way, at least that I saw was 

1 - cos(4x) 

= 1 - cos(2(2x)) 

= 1 - (1 - 2sin^2(2x)) by the cos double angle 

= 1 - 1 + 2sin^2(2x) 

= 2sin^2(2x)

1-cos(4x)

=1-cos(2x+2x)

=1-(cos2(2x)-sin2(2x)) -> trig identity cos(x+y)=cos(x)cos(y)-sin(x)sin(y)

=1-(1-sin2(2x)-sin2(2x)) -> cos2(a) = 1-sin2(a)

=1-1+sin2(2x)+sin2(2x)

=2 sin2(2x)

Question:
Trig substitution triangles:

Is there a way to think logically about how to label the triangles when doing trig substitutions? In other words, how do I know which side to label with x, and which one to label with the pattern, and how much to multiply these values by?

I've just been memorizing the triangles, but there must be a more intuitive way to go about this?
Answer:
It's all based on your original substitution. If, for example, you have made the substitution $$x=2\sin\theta$$, this is the same as saying 

$$\displaystyle \sin\theta=\frac{x}{2}=\frac{\text{opposite}}{\text{hypotenuse}}$$

So you should be drawing a right triangle with opposite side $$x$$ and hypotenuse $$2$$ and then solving for the remaining side using Pythagoras. 

Similarly, if you had made the substitution $$x=3\sec\theta$$, this is the same as saying 

$$\displaystyle \sec\theta=\frac{x}{3}=\frac{\text{hypotenuse}}{\text{adjacent}}$$

So you should be drawing a right triangle with adjacent side $$3$$ and hypotenuse $$x$$ and then solving for the remaining side using Pythagoras.

Question:
Deriving a trigonometric identity from another Section 2.1 Ex 1:

In example 1 of section 2.1, the following identity is used

$$cos^2x = \frac{1+cos(2x)}{2}$$

I tried deriving it using the pythagorean identity

=> $$cos^2x + sin^2x = 1$$

=> $$cos^2x = 1 - sin^2x$$

=> $$cos^2x = 1 - (\frac{1-cos(2x)}{2})$$

Using the fact that,$$cos(2x) = 1 - 2sin^2x$$,  $$2 sin^2x = 1 -cos(2x)$$ therefore: $$sin^2x = \frac{1-cos(2x)}{2}$$

I am confused as what I am missing to get

$$cos^2x = \frac{1+cos(2x)}{2}$$ instead of $$cos^2x = 1 - (\frac{1-cos(2x)}{2})$$
Answer: <md>This is known as the half-angle identity. Your process was correct, just simply replace 1 as $$\frac{2}{2}$$ (find the common denominator) and then subtract $$\frac{1-cos(2x)}{2}$$ will give you $$\frac{1+cos(2x)}{2}$$.</md>

Question:
Trig Substitution - inverse secant:

Hello!

Let's say we let $$x = 4\sec{\theta}$$, then $$\theta = \sec^{-1}{(\frac{x}{4})}$$. 

Why do we restrict the domain to $$\theta \in [0, \frac{\pi}{2}] \cup [\pi, \frac{3\pi}{2}]$$?

I thought that the range of the $$arcsec$$ function is $$[0, \frac{\pi}{2}) \cup (\frac{\pi}{2}, \pi]$$.

Thank you :)
Answer:
<md>I don't think it has anything to do with the arcsec function. 
When you let $$x = sec\theta$$, the purpose is to use one of the trig identities, namely $$\sqrt{(sec^{2}\theta -1)} = \sqrt{tan^{2}\theta} = |tan\theta|$$. In order to get rid of the absolute value sign, $$tan\theta$$ has to be positive, and that happens when $$\theta\in [0,\frac{\pi}{2}) \cup [\pi, \frac{3\pi}{2})$$. Open intervals because $$cos \frac{\pi}{2}$$ and $$cos \frac{3\pi}{2}$$ are 0.</md>
<md>I don't think it has anything to do with the arcsec function. 
When you let $$x = sec\theta$$, the purpose is to use one of the trig identities, namely $$\sqrt{(sec^{2}\theta -1)} = \sqrt{tan^{2}\theta} = |tan\theta|$$. In order to get rid of the absolute value sign, $$tan\theta$$ has to be positive, and that happens when $$\theta\in [0,\frac{\pi}{2}) \cup [\pi, \frac{3\pi}{2})$$.</md>

Question: Dropping absolute value signs in trig sub.: Hi I was wondering what intervals we know to choose for thetha when doing trig sub such that we can drop absolute value signs?
Answer:
For $$x=\sin\theta$$: $$\theta\in\left[\frac{-\pi}{2},\frac{\pi}{2}\right]$$

For $$x=\tan\theta$$: $$\theta\in\left(\frac{-\pi}{2},\frac{\pi}{2}\right)$$.

For $$x=\sec\theta$$: $$\theta\in\left[0,\frac{\pi}{2}\right)\cup\left[\pi,\frac{3\pi}{2}\right).$$

Question:
Separating common denominator:

Hi. Could anyone explain why we can't just separate the denominator into (2x+1) and (x-2)^2? I think for these two their common multiple would also be (2x+1)(x-2)^2. Why Instead we should have (x+2) too?
Answer:
The rules you've been told for breaking up the factors allow you to separate anything of the form $$\frac{P(x)}{Q(x)}$$ into partial fractions, where $$\deg(P(x))<\deg(Q(x))$$.

If you were to use only $$\frac{A}{2x+1}+\frac{B}{(x-2)^2}$$, could you really represent any function of the form $$\frac{P(x)}{(2x+1)(x-2)^2}$$, where $$\deg(P(x))<\deg((2x+1)(x-2)^2)=3$$? Are there $$A$$ and $$B$$, for instance, that allow you to write $$\frac{x^2}{(2x+1)(x-2)^2}=\frac{A}{2x+1}+\frac{B}{(x-2)^2}$$? Try finding them -- I think you'll see you hit a wall.

Any help would be appreciated!
Answer: Integrals with an $$x$$ in the bounds are still definite integral, so all properties for definite integrals apply here. And basically all properties about definite integrals will extend to indefinite integrals, except properties that have to do with the bounds of the integral (since indefinite integrals don't have bounds!)

Question: Week3 Practice Problem Q3: Hi, for the Q3, why we still have Constant at the end of the answer? The previous two integrals have been emitted.
Answer: The indefinite integral on the left can't simply be $$xe^{x^2}$$ -- it's the collection of all antiderivatives of a given function. Since we can always add a constant to an antiderivative to generate new antiderivatives, the $$+C$$ must be present. The indefinite integral on the left can't simply be $$xe^{^2}$$ -- it's the collection of all antiderivatives of a given function. Since we can always add a constant to an antiderivative to generate new antiderivatives, the $$+C$$ must be present.

Question: The Second Big Integration Worksheet q2: The answer for this question is $$sec^{-1}\left | x \right | + C$$. Why do we need to take the absolute value of x?
Answer: The big integration worksheet has been used in many past offerings of the course. I'm not sure what conventions were in place when the worksheet was created, but in our course, it is standard to use the domain $$\theta\in[0,\pi/2)\cup[\pi,3\pi/2)$$ for the $$x=\sec\theta$$ substitution. For this range of $$\theta$$'s, it turns out that $$\tan\theta\geq 0$$, and this is what allows us to "drop" the absolute values during the calculation. Some texts will instead use $$\theta\in[0,\pi/2)\cup(\pi/2,\pi]$$ for the $$x=\sec\theta$$ sub, which does not have the advantage of $$\tan\theta$$ being positive on this domain. So, in our course, as long as you stick with the domain $$\theta\in[0,\pi/2)\cup[\pi,3\pi/2)$$, the absolute value will disappear in these examples.

Question: best technique for integration?: I have been working on the integration questions in the practice problems, but I keep using the wrong integration methods. How do you know which technique is the most efficient to use to integrate a given integral ? especially the integrals involving multiple functions like the last few on the practice problems?
Answer: It's very integrand-dependent. If you see compositions, probably a substitution. If you see square roots with quadratics, could be trig sub -- possibly with a complete the square. If you see a product of unrelated functions, likely IBP. If you see a rational function, polynomial long division and partial fractions. Of course, the best way to build intuition for choosing a good intuition technique is to practice, practice, practice, then practice some more.

Question:
When to do trig sub vs u sub on square root denominator questions...:

I noticed that the solutions often simply do u-sub rather than trig sub... for example,

I was wondering if we just simply default to u-sub when it comes to equations with multiple xs in them? And is it still possible to do with trig sub?
Answer:
There may be multiple methods that work for a given problem. For instance, $$\displaystyle\int\frac{1}{x^2+4}\,dx$$ can be solved with the trig sub $$x=2\tan\theta$$; but it can also be solved with the $$u$$-sub $$x=\frac{u}{2}$$ upon noting that 

$$\frac{1}{x^2+4}=\frac{1}{4}\frac{1}{\frac{x^2}{4}+1}=\frac{1}{4}\frac{1}{\left(\frac{x}{2}\right)^2+1}.$$

For me, the trig sub feels more "obvious" here, but that's purely based on preference.

Similarly, $$\displaystyle\int \frac{x}{x^2+4}\,dx$$ can be solved with the trig sub $$x=2\tan\theta$$; but it can also be solved with the $$u$$-sub $$u=x^2+4$$. For me, the $$u$$-sub stands out as more obvious this time. 

The moral: Often, multiple methods are possible. The more you practice, the more intuition you'll build for what method to use, when.

$$\frac{1}{x^2+4}=\frac{1}{4}\frac{1}{\frac{x^2}{4}+1}=\frac{1}{4}\frac{1}{\left(\frac{x}{2}\right)^2+1}.$$

For me, the trig sub feels more "obvious" here, but that's purely based on preference.

Similarly, $$\displaystyle\int \frac{x}{x^2+4}\,dx$$ can be solved with the trig sub $$x=2\tan\theta$$; but it can also be solved with the $$u$$-sub $$u=x^2+4$$. For me, the $$u$$-sub stands out as more obvious this time. 

The moral: Often, multiple methods are possible. The more your practice, the more intuition you'll build for what method to use, when.

Question:
Type 1 improper integrals:

How do you evaluate the limits with b like algebraically
Answer:
If I understand your question correctly, the confusion is how to evaluate $$\displaystyle \lim_{b\to\infty} \frac{b^{1-p}-1}{1-p} = \lim_{b\to\infty} \frac{b^{1-p}}{1-p} + \frac{1}{p-1}$$? 

First, let's note that $$\frac{1}{p-1}$$ is a constant and so the limit doesn't affect it and we just need to determine $$\displaystyle \lim_{b\to\infty} \frac{b^{1-p}}{1-p} = \frac{1}{1-p} \lim_{b\to\infty} b^{1-p}$$.

Let's re-frame this as $$\displaystyle \lim_{x\to\infty} x^\alpha$$. We know that if $$\alpha < 0 $$, then the limit converges to $$0$$ and if $$\alpha > 0 $$ then the limit diverges to $$\infty$$. ($$\alpha =0$$ also converges but we'll see that this is equivalent to $$p=1$$ which diverges as shown in the final case.)

Similarly, $$\displaystyle \lim_{b\to\infty} b^{1-p}$$ is going to converge if $$1-p < 0$$, so $$p>1$$, and diverge if $$1-p>0$$, so $$p<1$$.

Question: Question bout type II improper integral definition: I am confused about how this definition works. Why can we just ignore half part of the bound and only deal with the left or right side of one of the bound? Only evaluating one side will definitely lose some area, so why it is equal to the original integral? Thank you
Answer: My understanding is that we are only trying to measure the area of a certain portion of the function, so we don’t need to look at anything outside the given bounds. So, instead of having an infinite discontinuity, we redefine our interval with $$t\to a^+$$ (shown below) so that we can actually find the value. Our limit assumes that we will never reach $$a$$, so we don’t need to worry about the discontinuity anymore, but we also haven’t lost any area: we only lost the finite point of $$x=a$$ and one of our properties tells us that the integral from a to a is 0.

Question:
invalid u sub?:

if i have a question like this, why can't i let u = sinx * cosx? when i adjust the bounds i end up getting that both endpoints are 0 (degenerate integral). how do i know if a u sub could be wrong/lead to degenerate integral? should i avoid u subs like this and how should i handle this? i couldn't find cases like this in the official course notes, is there anywhere i could learn more about this? thank you!

edit: i just realized i made an arithmetic mistake so this particular example isn't valid, but the general question surrounding usubs that "zero" out the bounds still holds
Answer:
This is a great question!

Let's consider a specific example: $$\int_0^\pi \sin(x) \, dx = 2$$.

Now let's do a substitution of the form $$u = \sin(x)$$ and $$du = \cos(x) \, dx$$ and update the bounds $$x = 0 \Rightarrow u = 0 $$ and $$x = \pi \Rightarrow u=0$$ and we get $$\int_0^0 \frac{u}{\sqrt{1-u^2}} \, du = 0$$. However, this is inconsistent with our answer above (which is correct). So what did I do wrong here?

I'm going to make this question public and come back with the solution to our apparent contradiction in 24 hours (or so).

If you think you know the issue, please comment below! Good luck :D

EDIT: The issue is indeed related to invertibility. In the example given, $$\sin(x)$$ is not invertible on $$[0,\pi]$$, thus, before we do our change of variables, we split the integral into two parts, one from $$[0,\pi/2]$$ and the other $$[\pi/2, \pi]$$. We can then proceed as usual with change of variables but with $$\cos(x) = -\sqrt{1-u^2}$$ on the $$[\pi/2, \pi]$$ interval. This will result in the same value as above.

Note that this doesn't mean that substitution doesn't work with non-invertible functions, rather, we just need to take some extra caution by splitting definite integrals into intervals where the substitution remains invertible. (In general, the intended solutions to the problems we give you will not have this subtlety.)

A picture of my explanation can be seen in the below comments, but I think the answer more generally is:

Suppose $$f:X\to Y$$ is integrable for (at least) $$X=\{x\in\mathbb{R}:a\leq x \leq b\} : \forall x \in \mathbb{R}, \,\,b\geq a.$$ Then $$Y=\{f(x):a\leq x \leq b\}.$$ Your choices for $$f$$ must be injective (one-to-one) on $$a\leq x \leq b$$, or else the bounds a, b $$\subset X$$ may map to the same $$Y$$ value, causing the problem above.

graph it.

This is a neat question. I enjoyed reading through the discussion below. 

What you're really asking about here is the domain of a composition $$f(g(x))$$. Since the input, $$x$$, must first pass through $$g$$, we must remove any points that make $$g(x)$$ undefined. So, in the case of $$\frac{1}{x^{-2}}=\frac{1}{1/x^2},$$ the inner function, $$g(x)=\frac{1}{x^2}$$, is not defined at $$x=0$$. Therefore, $$x=0$$ is not a point in the domain of the function, despite it appearing to not be an issue once the expression is simplified.

Another classic example is $$y=(\sqrt{x})^2$$, which is $$x$$, but only for $$x\geq 0$$. If you plot it on geogebra, for example, you'll see that nothing is shown for $$x<0$$.

Question:
Practice Problems Q5b - Bounds of Integration:

I'm wondering why for the question below, we take our bounds of integration to be 0 -> 1 and not 0 -> 2?
Answer:
The functions intersect at (1,1), and the "inner" and "outer" functions swap; the integrals can't be subtracted from each other, as you may do normally. To avoid this, they integrated with respect to the y-axis! (You can see why "1" is the upper bound by imagining the y-axis is horizontal).

By integrating with respect to y, we can avoid having to add up adjacent portions of the enclosed area. Before doing this, we put the functions in terms of y:

$$x=y^4$$ is good.

$$y=\sqrt{2-x}\Leftrightarrow x=2-y^2$$.

We can now integrate w.r.t. the y-axis. In this case, the functions intersect at (1,1), and the "inner" and "outer" functions swap; the integrals can't be subtracted from each other, as you may do normally. To avoid this, they integrated with respect to the y-axis! (You can see why "1" is the upper bound by imagining the y-axis is horizontal).

$$g(x)=-\int\frac{\sin x}{x}dx$$

(Both non-elementary)

$$\Rightarrow \, \int \left( f(x) +g(x) \right ) dx\Rightarrow \int \left ((\frac{\sin x}{x}) +( - \frac{\sin x}{x})\right )dx\Rightarrow \int 0\,dx$$. This is an elementary antiderivative, therefore the question is false.

In addition to the counter-example provided, the idea behind this problem comes from Week 3 practice problem 3.

Question: General question about the condition of ACT: When applying ACT, is it necessary for |f(x)| and g(x) to be cts on[a,b]?
Answer: Integrability is required on [a,b). Note that since b tends to infinity, we can't satisfy the integrability criterion AT b, so we have an open bound for b. Remember, continuity $$\Rightarrow$$ integrability, but the converse is not true.

Question:
Questions regarding to ACT:

I notice for proving the "In particular" part, we are using comparison test. I am wondering why we don't need to assume g(x) and absolute f(x) is continuous [a, infinity)? I think f and g integrable does not imply continuity of f and g.
Answer:
We are taking an integral, therefore we require integrability, not continuity. You are correct that integrability $$\nRightarrow$$ continuity, but we don't require that here.

(Since f & g are integrable on [a,$$\infty$$), its implied that they exist on these this interval).

Question:
Picking outer graph:

How do I know in this case to pick y = sqrt(2-x) as the outer curve
Answer: @255, Since we are integrating w.r.t the y-axis, the upper curve we pick is the one which is further down the positive x-axis. Imagine the y-axis is horizontal, then the pink curve would be the upper curve! You can also think of it as $$\int \text{right} - \text{left} \, \,  dy$$. Notice that $$\text{right} - \text{left} \geq 0$$ and this is consistent with the idea that areas between curves is $$\geq 0$$.

Question:
ptest:

for p-test is the integral bound fixed, like the lower bound always 1?
Answer:
This is a very nice question. 

The lower bound should be $$\geq$$1, we don't want it to get too close to the vertical asymptote at x=0.

But Shonie what about lower bounds > 1?

Keep in mind that we are testing the convergence of a very very long interval, if your function were to diverge when using the bounds [23, +$$\infty )$$, then your function will still diverge if you choose:

1$$\leq$$ lower bound $$\leq$$ 23.

Note that if you find that your improper integral is convergent, then choosing a different lower bound will obviously change that finite value. Since the divergent integrals aren't finite, we could choose a bigger lower-bound, and it wouldn't make a difference.

"$$+\infty - 23\Rightarrow +\infty$$"

To add on to the explanation above, you can show this result by replacing the 1 in the lower limit of the integral with any number greater than 1, we can call this $$a$$.

Then by performing the same steps as seen on page 84 and 85 of the course notes we see that our conclusion remains the same.

However it is important to note that if we change the lower bound from 1 to $$a$$, we do not necessarily have that: $$\int_a^\infty \frac{1}{x^p} = \frac{1}{p-1} $$. Instead we would have: $$\int_a^\infty \frac{1}{x^p} = \frac{a}{p-1}$$ (provided that $$p>1$$).

Question:
Comparison Test doubt:

Hello! I just have a question about the condition $$0 \leq g(x) \leq f(x)$$ for the comparison test. 

If we take $$f(x)=e^{-x}$$ and $$g(x)=e^{-x^2}$$, should we stick to the original condition as "$$\leq$$" or we should say $$0 < g(x) \leq f(x)$$ $$\forall x \geq 1$$.

Thank you!
Answer:
If I understand your question correctly you're asking that if we have $$f(x)=e^{-x} \ \& \ g(x) = e^{-x^2}$$, when we apply the comparison test should we write

"since $$0 \leq g(x) \leq f(x) \forall x\geq 1$$ we know by the comparison test that ..."

or should we write

"since $$0 < g(x) \leq f(x) \forall x\geq 1$$ we know by the comparison test that ..."

If this is what you're asking then you can use either - this is because we see that if $$0 < g(x)$$ then it must be true that $$0 \leq g(x)$$. Although it is important to keep in mind that the theorem only requires $$0 \leq g(x)$$.

Question:
Can an area be rotated about a line it is on?:

Hi,

Basically the title, could an area like this:

Be rotated about the y axis instead of the x? if so what strategy would we end up using?
Answer:
If you do a $$360^\circ$$ rotation about a line that passed through the interior of the region, you're going to end up with solid regions that overlap. In this example, if you rotate about the $$y$$-axis and calculate the volume using shells, for example, you'll actually end up with double the true volume of the solid (since you actually produce the 3D shape after just a $$180^\circ$$ rotation). We wouldn't ask about something like this.

Question: Do all general solutions of DE's include a constant, C?:
Answer:
Yes

This is a good question, and for the most part the answer is "yes". Though I suppose one could cook up a DE with just one function as its general solution. Here's an example:

$$(y^\prime)^2+y^2=0$$

The only way to make a sum of squares $$0$$ is if both terms are $$0$$. In particular, $$y$$ must be $$0$$. Sure enough, $$y\equiv 0$$ is the one and only solution to the DE.

Question:
practice quiz mc 2:

I don't understand why the shell method work in this case. The 2$$\pi$$ x in the shell is the circumference of the base circle. However, in this case, the base of this solid is a half circle which is not a circle. In other world, the shell method finds the volume by treating the objects as they are made up by hollow cylinder, and sum up all the hollow cylinders. But in this case, there are only half hollow cylinders. The other half is not in the bound. Could some explain why the shell method still work?

Thank you
Answer:
The function $$f$$ is only a half circle (really, quarter circle since we're working over the interval $$[0,1]$$), however, each shell is still a full cylinder -- draw it out.

In general, the function $$f$$ doesn't have to be related to a circle in any way. When it's rotates about an axis, though, it will generate cylindrical shells that have a full circle as their base.

Question:
DE's video:

Can someone explain in a bit more detail how the MVT was applied here?
Answer:
Yeah this isn't super obvious, but I think what they're getting at is the the MVT can be used to prove that if a function has derivative $$0$$, then that function must be a constant function.

How does this help to show that any solution has the form $$f(x)=Ce^x$$?

Well... suppose that $$f$$ is a differentiable function satisfying $$f^\prime(x)=f(x)$$ and consider the function $$g(x)=\frac{f(x)}{e^x}$$. We have 

$$\begin{align*} g^\prime(x)&=\frac{f^\prime(x)e^x-f(x)e^x}{e^{2x}} \tag{by the quotient rule}\\ &=\frac{f^\prime(x)-f(x)}{e^{x}} \tag{cancelling $e^x$}\\ &=0 \tag{since $f^\prime(x)=f(x).$} \end{align*}$$

Since $$g^\prime(x)=0$$, $$g(x)=C$$ for some constant $$C$$. That is, $$\frac{f(x)}{e^x}=C$$, so $$f(x)=Ce^x$$.

Question: Functions of y and x: This might be a silly question, but I am confused about what functions of y and x are. Is function of y in the form of y=2x for example and function of x in the form of x = 2y ?
Answer:
A function of $$x$$ would be something of the form $$y=f(x)$$; so, for example, $$y=\sin(x)$$ or $$y=x^3+e^x+1$$.


A function of $$y$$ would instead have the form $$x=g(y)$$. For instance, $$x=y^2$$ or $$x=e^y.$$

A function of $$x$$ would be something of the form $$y=f(x)$$; so, for example, $$y=\sin(x)$$ or $$y=x^3+e^x+1$$.


A function of $$y$$, would instead have the form $$x=g(y)$$. For instance, $$x=y^2$$ or $$x=e^y.$$

Question:
How to read and interpret a direction field:

From the textbook, we have the differential equation:

I understand that the direction field is constructed by plotting the arrows (whose direction is y') given the values of x + y.

What I fail to understand is how we interpret the graph, and what it means to find the solution for y(0) = 1 and y(-1) = 0?

To me, the second graph looks like you are trying to find where y' = -1?
Answer:
A direction field gives you the different possible solution curves that would satisfy the differential equation. The more detailed you make this field (the more points you draw slopes for), the easier you can see the tangent lines connecting and lining up. You can now “connect the dots” between these tangents to find all the curves that satisfy the differential equation. It is a tool to predict the behaviour of these curves without knowing their formulas.

When we interpret these graphs, we aren’t solving for anything really. Its just a graphical representation of what the possible solutions to the differential equation looks like.

Think of it as, “if our solution to our differential equation went through the points (-1, 0), this would be the corresponding curve.”

And it follows that if our curve passed through the points (0, 1) as is the case in the image on the left, then that would be the corresponding curve.

All the curves obey the restriction of the differential equation, but are different from one another, a direction field lets us visualize all possible solutions to a differential equation.

Question:
Re: Linear first order DE:

In this example, how do you recognize that the first line equates to the third?
Answer:
After multiplying by the integrating factor $$\mu(x)$$, the LHS of a linear DE will always factor as $$(\mu(x)y)^\prime$$. A linear DE will always factor as $$(\mu(x)y)^\prime$$, where $$\mu(x)$$ is the integrating factor.

If you're wondering how to simply recognize they are equal, not how to actually find the third line, you can take the derivative of the left side of the third line and you should get the left side of the second line.

Here are the steps in case you're stuck:

$$\frac{d}{dx}(e^{x^2}y)$$

$$= \frac{d}{dx}e^{x^2}y + e^{x^2}\frac{d}{dx}y$$ (product rule)

$$=2xe^{x^2}y + e^{x^2}\frac{dy}{dx}$$

$$=e^{x^2}(2xy + \frac{dy}{dx})$$ (factor out $$e^{x^2}$$)

Question: Linear DE: What is a for sure way to know if the DE is linear or not?
Answer:
We look at all the terms with $$y, y', y''$$, etc. and basically see if anything "funky" is going on with them. Sometimes I think of it as looking for the highest power of $$y$$ (treating any derivative of $$y$$ as $$y$$) but there also cannot be any $$e^y, \sin(y), f(y)^2$$ and so on.

I'm not certain on how I can define a "for sure" way, because it requires a little investigating sometimes, so I would recommend understanding the variety of problems that could be linear or non-linear. I'll outline a couple random examples because I think they will help more than my explanation:

Linear:

$$e^x\cdot\cos(x^2+2x)y+y'\ln(x)=y''$$ 

There are no terms of $$y$$ doing anything "funky" like being in a trig function or being multiplied together, so this is linear

$$\frac{d^2y}{dx^2} = x^7y'''$$

This is kinda strange because it uses both derivative notations (so probably not good form) but I wanted to illustrate that $$\frac{d^2y}{dx^2} $$ is the same as $$y''$$ so this is also linear

Non-linear:

$$y\cdot y'=x$$

Since $$y$$ and $$y'$$ are multiplied together, it is non-linear

$$y^7=\cos(x)y'$$

This is a power of $$y$$ so non-linear (only powers of 1 are allowed)

$$\cos(y')=x+2$$

The $$y'$$ is in a trig function so non-linear

$$\sqrt y x+5 = y'$$

Fractional exponents are also not allowed

Here's a screenshot from lecture with more examples:

I hope that helps, maybe someone else has a more definite way of determining this, but this is what I do. I actually came up with some examples that confused me so I am gonna post them in a separate question if you want to refer to it as well.

The most general version of a linear ODE is

$$A_n(x) y^{(n)} + A_{n-1}(x) y^{(n-1)} + \dots + A_2(x) y'' + A_1(x) y' + A_0(x) y = B(x)$$,

where $$y^{(k)}$$ denotes the $$k$$-th derivative of $$y$$ and the $$A_k(x)$$ are any functions of $$x$$ (and not $$y$$).

Question:
Non-linear ODE's -- manipulated into linear ODE's?:

If we have an ODE that is non-linear at first glance, but it can be manipulated to appear as a linear ODE, would we say it is linear or non-linear? 

Here's the definition from the course notes for reference, I notice it specifically says "if it can be written in the form..." which implies that algebraic manipulation should be okay. 

Here are some examples of what I am confused about:

$$\frac{y}{y'}=x$$

If I move $$y'$$ to the other side then it becomes linear, and $$y\equiv0$$ wouldn't be in the domain(?) so I suppose this is a valid manipulation and it is linear?

$$\cos(y')=x$$

What if I rewrite as $$y' = \arccos(x)$$ (assuming I ensure my domain is invertible), would this count as linear?

$$\ln(y')=x$$

What if I manipulate this to be $$y' = e^x$$?

Thanks for your help!
Answer:
This is an interesting question. I would probably lean on the side of "yes, if you can modify the expression into $$y' + P(x) y =Q(x)$$, then it is a first order linear ODE" (and similar for anything higher order).

One subtly I suppose is that at least in the first equation, $$\frac{y}{y'} = x$$, we can't have any solutions that have $$y' \equiv 0$$. So my broader advice is that when you solve one of these ODEs (after transforming into a FOLDE), is that you check whether your solutions are all valid based on the original ODE.

Question:

We use the info given in the first part of that sentence 

$$T(2)= 80 \Rightarrow 80 = 75e^{-2k}+20 \Rightarrow 60 = 75e^{-2k} \Rightarrow \frac{60}{75} = e^{-2k} \Rightarrow \frac{4}{5}= e^{-2k}$$

Hope that helps!

Question: Constant/Equilibrium Solutions: For separable DE's, why is it that we denote them with the equivalence sign "≡" instead  of "="?
Answer:
My understanding is that this notation explicitly says "y is the constant function $$\alpha$$" instead of potentially implying that "y is $$\alpha$$ for certain values of x". 

For example, if I had $$y=5$$, then I could say $$y=x+4$$ when $$x=1$$ or something. 

However, $$y\equiv5$$ is just the constant function $$f(x) = 5, \forall x\in \mathbb{R}$$

The notation $$y\equiv \alpha$$ is more like saying $$f(x) = \alpha$$, so we know that it is the constant function and not another equation to solve. 

That's my take from what I've gathered from conversations with professors, I would appreciate if someone else could weigh in on this.

Question:
Linear DE:

Hi, could anyone help explain why we don't do the integral of the circled part? Thanks.
Answer:
The reason we do not compute $$\int \frac{1}{x} dx$$ is because there is a $$\ln(x)$$ factor to $$y'$$. At that point, we can also already rewrite the LHS as $$\frac{d(\ln(x)y)}{dx}$$.

To find the integrating factor, the $$y'$$ term should only have a factor of 1. In that case, the DE becomes $$y'  + \frac{y}{x\ln(x)} = \frac{e^x}{\ln(x)}$$. We can then integrate $$\frac{1}{x\ln(x)}$$ which equals $$\ln (\ln (x))$$ (choosing c = 0). By exponentiating this result, we get $$\mu (x) = \ln(x)$$, as obtained in the solution.

Question: When to use integration factor?: I am kind of confused when I should use the integration factor and when I directly do the integration on both sides? Some separable DEs can be rearranged to look like the separable form y' = f(x)g(y).
Answer:
If the equation is separable, go with integrating both sides because it’s usually easier. We use the FOLDE method with the integration factor generally when we cannot rewrite the equation as separable. That method takes longer (at least from my experience) so the separable method is preferable.

Question: differentiation equation constant solution: For a separable differential equation, we need to check the constant solutions by finding all the values of y0 such that g(y0) = 0. Why for the first order differential equation, we don't need to check the constant solution? Thank you
Answer:
For a separable ODE, $$y' = g(y) h(x)$$, you first divide by $$g(y)$$ and then integrate both sides. This means that you are implicitly assuming that $$g(y) \not \equiv 0$$, so solutions of that form may be missed. Hence, we check whether $$g(y) \equiv 0$$ also satisfies the ODE.

For FOLDEs, we don't run into the same issue and all solutions are given by the final expression in Step 3.

Question:
[Week bf MT PP] Q2c):

Hi, for this part y = 1 + $$\frac{C}{(x^2+1)^{3/2}}$$, is it appropriate if I write y = 1 + C directly and I will get specific solution y = 1 + 1 in the end. Thanks :D
Answer:
If you are asking whether you can absorb the $$\dfrac{C}{(x^2+1)^{3/2}}$$ into a single constant $$C_0$$, then that would be incorrect.

The only time you can absorb stuff into an arbitrary constant is if the other parts are also constants.

To give you some concrete examples:

$$C_0 = 2+C$$, $$C_0 = C/2$$, $$C_0 = 4C, C_0 = e^{C}$$, etc are all valid, but

$$C_0 = C/x$$, $$C_0 = Cx^2$$ are NOT valid.

A particular solution is still a function, so I don’t think that solution would be appropriate. We first solve for C by plugging in our initial condition $$y(0)=2$$, then we rewrite the general solution by replacing C to get our particular solution. 

What you are describing is the specific y-value when x=0, however when we are looking for a particular solution, we want a function y=f(x) where we can use any value of x in the domain. 

Essentially, the only reason the denominator disappeared on the C term was because it becomes 1 with our initial condition. 

What I like to think of is that our general solution looks like a direction field, and our IC specifies which particular solution we want in the direction field. 

That was a lot of words so please let me know if you need clarification! The bottom line is that 2= 1 + C is only 1 point in our particular solution, so we can’t use it as the final answer.

Question:
Midterm 2023 MC:

Wouldn't it become e^-3lnx = 1/x^3 which does not match any answers
Answer:
"An" is doing the heavy lifting here.

The formula for an integrating factor is $$e^{\int P(x) \, dx}$$ and in the exponent we have $$\int -\frac{3}{x} \, dx = -3\ln(x) + C = \ln(x^{-3}) + C$$, after exponentiating, we get $$e^{\ln(x^{-3}) + C} = Ax^{-3}$$.

Typically, we throw away the constant because it drops out after we multiply everything through by the integrating factor.

Question: When can a volume of revolution question not be done with a method?: When can a volume of revolution question not be done with one of the methods? I just feel like shouldn't every problem be able to be done by both methods?
Answer:
Theoretically I guess every problem can be done using both methods, however one method requires us to invert the function, which is very difficult and impractical sometimes. 

For example, if I have some strange function like $$y=e^{\frac{\cos(2x^2 + 3}{\log_{5}(x^{-3})}}$$ or something equally horrific, it would be quite a pain to invert and use the other method. Plus it might have domain problems when you invert it. 

Sometimes it’s pretty straightforward to use either method but usually there’s an « easier » way and a « harder » way

Question:
"f integrable on [a.b] for each a ≤ b": In the line "let f be integrable on [a,b] for each a ≤ b", 
I assume a,b are arbitrary, so does this mean f is integrable everywhere a closed interval can be created? i.e. everywhere except infinity?
Or am I reading too much into it and it just says an interval [a,b] where the start of the interval is ≤ end of the interval
Answer:
It's saying that $$f$$ is integrable on every interval of the form $$[a,b]$$, where $$a$$ and $$b$$ can be any numbers with $$a\leq b$$. So, $$f$$ is integrable on $$[0,1]$$ and on $$[2,5]$$, and on $$[\pi,2\pi]$$, etc.

Though, really, I suppose that in this definition $$a$$ can be fixed, and we would just require that $$f$$ be integrable on any interval $$[a,b]$$, where $$b$$ can be anything $$\geq a$$. The reason is that we need to be able to compute the integral $$\int_a^bf(x)\,dx$$ for an arbitrary $$b$$ -- then we'll take the limit as $$b\rightarrow\infty.$$

It's saying that $$f$$ is integrable on every interval of the form $$[a,b]$$, where $$a$$ and $$b$$ can be any numbers with $$a\leq b$$. So, $$f$$ is integrable on $$[0,1]$$ and on $$[2,5]$$, and on $$[\pi,2\pi]$$, etc.

Question: Existence and Uniqueness Theorem for First-Order Linear Differential Equations: Could someone explain when I would know there is a unique solution?
Answer:
So a FOLDE is of the form $$y' = f(x)y+g(x)$$. If it cannot be written in this form, it is not a FOLDE. 

With that given, if $$f(x)$$ and $$g(x)$$ are both continuous functions on some interval $$I$$, we know that for any value of $$x_0\in I$$ and for all values of $$y_0 \in \mathbb{R}$$ we have exactly one solution (there exists a solution AND it's the only one).

That's me parroting what the theorem says. In more practical terms, I think of it like a checklist of sorts:

1) is it a FOLDE? 

2) are $$f(x)$$ and $$g(x)$$ continuous?

If those two conditions are true, you are guaranteed a unique solution by this theorem, regardless of $$x_0$$ and $$y_0$$.

I hope that clears things up for you, let me know if you have more questions!

Question: Practice Problem 6 q7b(i): I wonder why can we take off the absolute sign directly
Answer:
Imagine if you left the absolute value sign there and then multiplied both sides of the DE by $$\mu(x)=\frac{1}{|x|}$$. That is, you're multiplying by $$\frac{\pm 1}{x}$$ depending on the sign of $$x$$. Notice that the $$\pm$$ on the LHS of the DE will just cancel off with the other $$\pm$$ on the RHS of the DE. So, it doesn't matter whether you include the absolute value or not -- the result will be the same once everything is multiplied into the DE.
Imagine if you left the absolute value sign there and then multiplied both sides of the DE by $$\mu(x)=\frac{1}{|x|}$$. That is, you're multiplying by $$\frac{\pm 1}{x}$$ depending on the sign of $$x$$. Notice that the $$\pm$$ one the LHS of the DE will just cancel off with the other $$\pm$$ on the RHS of the DE. Question: Trig Sub Integral???: I am having some difficulty with integrating in the form $$f(x)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{x^2+a^2}}$$. I tried to use trig sub but got stuck at integral of sec(x). Is this the correct approach? How do we integrate sec(x)? Is it a common integral (to memorize)? It's not in the table in the course notes?
Answer:
$$\int \sec(u) \, du$$ requires a trick that we would likely give you. Specifically, you need to multiply by $$\displaystyle \frac{\sec(u) + \tan(u)}{\sec(u) + \tan(u)}$$ and then use a substitution $$v = \sec(u) + \tan(u)$$. From there, you should find that

$$\displaystyle \int \sec(u) \, du = \ln|sec(u) + \tan(u)| + C$$.

We covered $$\int sec(x)$$ sometime during lecture, I think it was right before we learned trig sub. To actually solve it we had to use a trick (multiplying by a convenient choice of 1), here's a picture from my notes of how we did it:

Personally, I just memorized the integral, and there's a chance we would be given this integral as a hint on the midterm but I would be sure to know it just in case.

Hope that helps!

Question:
question about mcq3:

for this example, isnt (fx)^(1/3)' integral on 0-infinity still convergent?
Answer:
For $$\displaystyle f(x) =\begin{cases} \dfrac{1}{x^3} & \text{ if } x \geq 1 \\ 1 & \text{ otherwise} \end{cases} $$, we would find that $$\displaystyle \int_0^\infty f(x) \, dx$$ converges using $$p$$-test.

On the other hand, we would find $$\int_0^\infty (f(x))^{1/3} \, dx$$ will diverging because, for $$x\geq 1$$, $$(f(x))^{1/3} = \frac{1}{x}$$ and we know that $$\int_1^\infty \frac{1}{x} \, dx$$ diverges by $$p$$-test.

Question: Can anyone explain this step please:
Answer:
We are adding the part I circled in red to both sides, so we have $$I_n + (n-1)I_n$$ on the left side, which simplifies to just $$nI_n$$, and the $$(n-1)I_n$$ part cancels out on the right side. 

Then, the final step is to divide everything by $$n$$ so we just have $$I_n$$ on the left side and everything else is on the right side.

Hope that helps!

Questiona about partial fraction decomposition: Why if I try to use partial fraction decomposition on $$\frac{x}{(x^2+3)^2}$$, what  I got is still $$\frac{x}{(x^2+3)^2}$$. Won't the partial fraction decomposition give me a simpler version of a fraction? Thank you
Answer: It's already in its simplest form: $$\frac{x}{(x^2+3)^2}$$ will decompose as $$\frac{Ax+B}{x^2+3}+\frac{Cx+D}{(x^2+3)^2}$$, which is already what you have.

Question: integrating factor: May someone from Eric class explain that why the integration factor in the slides midterm u(x) is different from the course note I. ( missing a negative sign). Thank you.
Answer:
I was confused about that too but the difference is where $$f(x)$$ is located in the equation. 

Eric uses $$y’ +f(x)y=g(x)$$ so we have $$\mu(x) =e^{+\int f(x)}$$

The textbook uses $$y’ = f(x)y +g(x)$$ so they get the extra negative $$\mu(x)=e^{-\int f(x)}$$

Hope that helps!

now use the u-sub $$u = tanx$$ and see what you get

Question: comparison test: does the comparison test for type I improper integral only apply to positive function?
Answer: To be really specific, it applies to « non-negative functions » so you can have functions that equal 0. But they can’t be negative because then our conditions in the theorem won’t hold

Question:
Midterm 23 Q5:

Can I say since $$\lim_{x\to \infty} \frac{lnx}{x^{\frac{9}{4}}} = 0$$,the numerator grows slower than the denominator, then converges?
Answer:
If you have a function $$f(x)$$ such that $$\lim_{x\to\infty} f(x) = 0$$, that is NOT enough to conclude that $$\int_1^\infty f(x) \,dx$$ converges. For example, $$\frac{1}{x} \to 0$$ as $$x\to \infty$$ but $$\int_1^\infty \frac{1}{x} \, dx$$ diverges.


On other hand, it is the case that if $$\lim_{x\to\infty} f(x) \neq 0$$ then $$\int_1^\infty f(x) \, dx$$ diverges.

Question: MT22 Q8 (b): Hi, I am wondering why we need to separate the integral into two parts (type 1 part and type 2 part) here
Answer:
We have to check if both converge to see if the overall integral converges. We don't have a method of checking both of these problems at the same time, so we have to split them up. Then we can deal with them as a type 1 and type 2 integral individually, which we know how to do.

Bottom line is we have to be careful about all the improper parts of the integral, so keep an eye out for all discontinuities and bounds to infinity.

Question: Quiz 5 MC: I'm a bit confused on how to determine the linearity/order of DEs, for Q1, a) is not linear because of the sin(xy)? b) is not linear because of the 2^y'? And for Q2, why is a) not second order but b) is?
Answer:
Order refers to the highest derivative in the DE, (b) has y'', none of the others have a second derivative of y. A very common misunderstanding is that the highest power in the DE is the order, this is wrong; (a) has no second derivatives of y.

Question:
When to check for constant solutions in differential equations?: For initial value problems, when do I know to check for constant solutions and how do I know whether they satisfy my initial condition?

If it's not an initial value problem, do you still have to consider constant solutions?
Answer:
You need to check constant solutions whenever you divide by an expression involving $$y$$ while solving a DE. You need to make sure that that expression is not $$0$$. For example, if you solve the separable DE $$\frac{dy}{dx}=(y^2-1)x$$, your first step is to divide by $$y^2-1$$ -- but what if $$y^2-1=0$$, i.e, $$y\equiv 1$$ or $$y\equiv -1$$? You would need to check those functions separately. In the case of an IVP, if the constant function doesn't satisfy your initial condition, I suppose you can quickly rule it out as a potential solution.
You need to check constant solutions whenever you divide by an expression involving $$y$$ while solving a DE. You need to make sure that that expression is not $$0$$. For example, if you solve the separable DE $$\frac{dy}{dx}=(y^2-1)x$$, your first step is to divide by $$y^2-1$$ -- but what if $$y^2-1=0, i.e, $$y\equiv 1$$ or $$y\equiv -1$$? You would need to check those functions separately. In the case of an IVP, if the constant function doesn't satisfy your initial condition, I suppose you can quickly rule it out as a potential solution.
